utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Honey? Are you alright?

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Yeah. Yeah, just fighting off a stomach bug. I'll be fine. Did he sleep ok?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Great. As long as I was holding him. Can't wait for colic to be over. Oh shhh... come on Mikey, bathtub's coming. He lifted his head yesterday. Take the day off, I mean you're sick anyway and you hardly ever see him. Or me.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: I can't. I got a meeting with Crandall's kitchens; I think that deal's going to close.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: They called about the car payment again. Its two months late.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: We're going to be fine, honey. Enjoy your bath little man

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You know honey; I don't think I'm going to go in. I'm coming down with something. Honey? Kara? Kara? Kara! Mikey! Mikey! Kara! Mikey!

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: 4-week old infant submerged in the bathtub. Don't know how long, non-responsive at the scene.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Obviously breathing now. Continue to blow by stat portable test.

utterance.speaker: EMT
utterance.content: Caucasian female, 32, catatonic seizure in the bathroom.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Where... where am I?

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You're in the hospital, honey, you're in the hospital. Mikey's here and the doctor say he's going to be ok.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hopefully. He needs to be checked out by the NICU.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You passed out.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Mikey fell.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Has your wife had a seizure before?

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: I can't move my head, I want to see him!

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: He's right here, honey, he's ok, he's right here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tonight. L Word marathon.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You watch the L Word?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On mute.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'll pass. Dinner with Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Still sucking up so she'll fund your play space for the chemo kids? They really ought to save their energy for other things. Like crying.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She's the suck up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She asked you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She's smart. She knows if she buys me enough alcohol, my defences just might be weakened.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doesn't make sense. Unless she ran out of batteries.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hey, I'm recently single, she's single.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're too nice for her to like you; she's not needy enough for you to like her. She's got an agenda, just not one that includes an appearance by 'little Jimmy'. I'll poll my peeps. How many of you think that Cuddy asked-- or rather peep.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Chase got a case in the ER; he wants us to take a look.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless Chase broke his neck falling off his polo pony, he had no reason to be in the ER.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Cuddy put him on a 2-week NICU rotation. Patient had an unexplained seizure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seizures are cool to watch, boring to diagnose. What about Foreman? He needs to get his malingering butt back here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He almost died.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Almost being the operative word .

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hey. How are you doing? You look great.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thanks. I feel great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Glad you're back. Cameron makes lousy coffee. Take mine black, the way I take my brain-damaged neurologists.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Happy to help.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How are you coming along?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell her everything is great. Neither of us wants to deal with her guilt.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don't feel guilty.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course not, hell if people felt guilt every time they accidentally lobotomised a guy...

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I was trying to save his life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, your heart was in the right place. It's just his brain that's not quite where it's supposed to be. Tell her everything's great.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's true. No more left-side right-side reversals, still some short-term memory loss and spatial processing problems but trying not to be too hard on myself.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, might pull a muscle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We have a case?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Seizure that can't be explained by epilepsy. And accompanied by elevated calcium levels.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Still bored. Tell her why.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Because seizure with mildly elevated calcium is diagnostically simple. It's either hyper parathyroid, cancer or calcium-mediated neurotoxicity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well done. But until you can remember how to make coffee, hands off the patients.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House. All those reasons this case bores you, the ER has already ruled them out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lungs are clear, get an EEG, confirm that brain functions are ok.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can we focus on the task at hand? Why did mommy twitch so hard she tossed the baby in with the bathwater?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You don't need me for this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course I need you, we're a team.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Polyarteritis nodosa. Inflamed arteries in the brain cause seizures, inflamed arteries in the kidneys cause calcium build-up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're a moron; did you even look at the file? Kidney functions fine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Whipple's.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Whipple's.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Test her. Cameron thinks it starts with a "w"; I'm thinking "v".

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Dad vomited this morning, maybe they've both got strep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Think you can do a strep throat culture without the swab ending up in the guy's poop chute?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: V for vasoconstriction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta be my guess.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Excess calcium makes blood vessels in the brain clamp down, best case scenario, seizure; worst case, stroke.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do a digital subtraction angiogram. Foreman can't tell up from down and Cameron's a girl - all that mechanical stuff.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry, Cuddy says I'm stuck here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're late.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you are in my locked office. Again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What you got there? Special panties for your date with Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's not a date and it's none of your business.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not a date, it is business. And if it was business, you wouldn't say it was none of my business.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What do you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want to talk about your date with Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's not a date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is fun. Spring Chase from NICU and I'll shut up about your date.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: NICU is short-staffed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you suddenly lost the ability to lie? Nobody's quit NICU in two years. And if you're making up reasons, that means there is no reason. Which means he asked for the assignment, didn't he?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If Chase needs a break from you, he should take it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Both mom and dad are negative for strep.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You'll be back playing with the big toys soon.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or not. Either way I'm fine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don't have to say that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's ok. I can always work in a research lab or teach.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And you'd be ok with that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why wouldn't I be?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You were planning on pursuing grants of your own, running a department.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm alive. Changing jobs, not making coffee... if that stuff bothers me now, I don't deserve this second chance.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They say that physical contact helps the healing process.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: What's happening?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Your son's not getting enough oxygen, take Mr Mason outside.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lung's collapsed, he's not getting any air, I need an IV catheter!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Another seizure?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her chest muscles aren't contracting, it's something else. Her whole back is spasming, two milligrams of diazepam, stat.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: He's ok.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His lung wouldn't have collapsed if he was ok.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What the hell is happening?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I have no idea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what causes seizures, hypercalcemia and the thing where mommy bends like Gumby?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A little busy here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh oh, baby's lungs are going to conk out any minute. Probably want to deal with that.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'll get right on it as soon as I finish indulging my boss.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Multi-task.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Chemical pneumonitis. Bubble bath got into the baby's lungs when he was underwater. Start him on prednisone; keep him on high FIO2 .

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let the indulging commence.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lithium could cause all 3 of the mother's symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No record she's on lithium.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And tox screen was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lithium doesn't show on a basic tox screen, scarecrow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Myelogenous meningitis could also cover everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Rare complications of a rare blood cancer. You're not totally hopeless. Get an S-pep and an MRI for the myelogenous meningitis . Search the patient's place for lithium . Baby's lung problem is bacterial, not chemical, start ECMO . While you're searching for the lithium, take a water sample and check the pipes. You want me to write this down for you? I ask you, is almost dying, any excuse for not being fun?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm not putting that baby on ECMO, the chance of there being bacteria in bathwater--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don't you want to work for me? I'm nice, I'm fun at parties.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm not working NICU because of you. The baby's x-ray suggests a chemical pneumonitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not to me. X-ray was too consolidated. So why are you down here? Hoping to expand your make out pool to include the preme to nine-year-old demographic?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I needed a break. From the patients. They lie to us all the time, Foreman almost died trying to save a drug-dealing cop. I just wanted to get away from that for a while.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What a complete load of crap. What am I a nurse you're trying to prep with this vulnerability thing?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: ECMO could kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't start him on ECMO and that infection could rampage through his body like pistons fans after a championship. But you do it your way. Nothing more honest than a dead baby

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: ECMO stands for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation; basically we remove your son's blood--

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: All of his blood?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We run it through a machine which takes out carbon dioxide and adds oxygen. Then we re-warm the blood and run it back into his body. There is a significant risk of internal haemorrhaging and he may also suffer from--

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You put him on antibiotics; won't that take care of the infection?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not fast enough.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Are you sure this is Mikey's best shot?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Absolutely.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy's trash?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not anymore. Paid good money for it. Look at what she bought.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Red clover.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What is red clover used for, Dr Wilson?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Also used to treat asthma, psoriasis, joint pain...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She doesn't wheeze, flake or ache. And she didn't ask a pulmonologist or a dermatologist for dinner. She invited an oncologist. It's not a date, it's a consult.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Mom's MRI was negative for masses, abscesses, there's no sign that she has myelogenous meningitis--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fascinating, call me when we have--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She has a subarachnoid bleed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So why is our patient bleeding into her brain?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her blood workup shows her ProTime's elevated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's bleeding because she's not clotting. So why is she not clotting? What'd you bring us, daddy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The only mood altering drug was vodka, at the back of her drawer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hiding booze is classic alcoholic behaviour, that'd explain the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What bleeding?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't remember? She bled all over you this morning . Kidding. Idiots are fun; no wonder every village wants one.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If she's an alcoholic, she would also be more prone to hypercalcemia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But tox screen was negative for alcohol.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, it was your idea. Now it's even better. Mommy quits, she gets the DTs, it even explains the seizure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Also fits conversion disorder. They're deep in debt, he's working round the clock, they got a new baby - I think the seizure was a physical response to psychological stress.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Boozing mommy covers more symptoms. Put her in a nice Phenobarbital coma before the DTs kill her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: To put her in a phenocoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if I'm wrong? What if daddy's the drunk?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you want us to give her the pheno or not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want him to argue his point!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I assume you considered the father and ruled him out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's that saying where you ASSume you become a pain in the ass to me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why should I argue? You'd just overrule me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Enough! Get a pony or a watermelon farm!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need him to react; I need him to act like a human being. I need him to get over this boring, near-death rebirth.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I have changed. It's not something you get over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nearly dying changes everything forever. For about 2 months. 2 months is too long, I need the guy I hired back now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No matter how much your misery loves company, it's not getting mine. I'll talk to the dad, Cameron can take the mom, we'll figure out if mom was a drinker.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Waste of time; put her in a coma before the DTs kill her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So... is this a separation or...?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Our lawyers have been hired, friends divvied up. Oddly she didn't fight me for House.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: At least there aren't kids involved. Just have each other to deal with.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm. If there had been kids, maybe we would have done more of that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do you want kids?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Listen, is there anything in particular you wanted to... hospital business or...?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Catching up. I mean, you know... it's not like either one of us has anybody to run home to.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How are you feeling?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Ok. A little groggy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's somebody here to see you.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Hey Mikey, mommy's awake.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Oh Mikey, oh gosh, I was so scared! Oh... I love you I love you so much, shh... I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You don't have anything to be sorry about. You were sick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Turns out she and her husband met in AA, obviously she slipped. Good call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It wasn't hard considering my other choice was your stupid psych theory. Which was not stupid. I'm telling you, I'm going to drop the "N" bomb if I have to.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're addicted to conflict.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did they change the name?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You could have handled this patient without dragging Chase in but the fact that he didn't want in killed you. Just like the fact that you can't get a rise out of me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where's the baby?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No breath sounds, crash cart and epi, stat! I told you your psych theory wasn't stupid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your son is stable but the lack of oxygen damaged his kidneys.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: She must have rolled over on him by mistake.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mr Mason, I was there. Your wife tried to smother your son.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: That's impossible. Kara would never hurt Mikey.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: He knows. They said Mikey knows.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You hear voices?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: They wouldn't quit saying that Mikey would be better off if... they were right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We've been trying to diagnose a seizure that didn't exist. She faked it when her husband caught her.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't think she faked it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She just happened to seize right in the middle of drowning her child? Lucky break for the kid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, take it easy on Foreman. He's playing with one lobe tied behind his back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Postpartum psychosis makes her want to drown her kid, the internal conflict triggers a seizure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know what else might be a trigger? A physical illness. It's a wild idea, I know especially since she doesn't have any obviously physical symptoms like internal bleeding or excess calcium.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'll draw some blood, test for--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ahhhh!! Jesus! You've done it again! Will you argue with me?! Drinkers don't eat right, explains the bleeding and the calcium, this might just be some crazy drunk and I'm telling you that she's about to die of myelogenous meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We already tested for--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly! It's an insane idea!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ok. What do you want me to do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have an original thought. In the meantime, stress her into having another seizure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can't, she's on Haloperidol.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You also can't because it's dangerous and highly unethical, therefore, if you get caught, pretend you can't make coffee, mental defectives get tons of slack. Take her off the Haloperidol, hook her up to an EEG, flash some lights, make her pant, shoot her up with a placebo. When she starts twitching, if the machine twitches along its real. If not, call the cops because she's a psycho killer.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Stop pushing him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stop protecting him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He needs it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not if he wants to get better.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He might not be able to get better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well then I need a new neurologist.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He got sick doing his job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well if he got killed doing his job I wouldn't keep him on the payroll. I don't care how guilty you feel, or how touched you are by his reborn spirit.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm not touched.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you're guilt-ridden.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm not guilt-ridden!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you're pathetic!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Right now I'm annoyed! Keeping him up all night in a seizure lab is not the way to advance his recovery, it's too much!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're right, should stick around, make sure he doesn't screw up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kara, look directly into the light. Keep looking. Thought you'd be gone for the day.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thought I'd wait for the bone marrow biopsy results.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House sent you to baby-sit me, didn't he?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He asked me to wait for the results.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron, its fine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 'Course it is.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look, a few weeks ago you were upset that I didn't consider you a friend. Now you're upset that I'm happy?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What can I say? Apparently I'm a bitch.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Woah! I didn't say that.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's annoying. Insisting every day of your life is a blessing is basically calling everyone else shallow. Gets old.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, give it a rest.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How was dinner?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cuddy did not mention cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She lost her nerve.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It was a date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: PCR test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're doing it yourself, in the middle of the night? On a spoon. Cuddy's spoon?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm checking her saliva for cancer markers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. I do that after all my dates too. People think you're the nice one.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why are you so worried about Cuddy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You go first. You desperately want this to be a date.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because the alternative is cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just admit that you like her. She's smart, funny, got a zesty bod. I think it's great you can look beyond the fact she's the devil.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I stole her spoon, you stole her garbage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's my boss. She gets sick, the hospital might replace her, especially if she dies. I'd have to learn how to manipulate someone new.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Woah. I think I'm going to cry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Find me when the results come in.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mr Mason, because of the damage done to your son's kidneys, his potassium is climbing. It's causing irregular heartbeats. I'm doubling the meds and starting him on dialysis. Unless we get his potassium down, he's going to have a heart attack.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Kara, just another few minutes.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Biopsy's back, she's negative for myelogenous meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And she's not seizing. So we're wrong and House is wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're ok with that? She's seizing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's not doing anything.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Brain activity isn't accelerating, it's slowing down.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Muscle rigidity, involuntary grasping and sucking motions, she's in an encephalopathic delirium.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm... a genuine physiological illness that rules out a few things. Like what I wonder?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Postpartum psychosis and conversion disorder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thing about being a good loser, you're still a loser.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Ouch.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The delirium means her brain is shutting down, reverting to its most instinctual functions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Since it's progressing, we can assume it's progressive. Which means it won't be long before the brain closes shop altogether. Ideas?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: He's in vfib!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Potassium's still too high. No pulse, get him off the machine. Charge it up to 10. Clear!

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Still in vfib.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Another amp of epi!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase shouldn't be wasting his time in the NICU.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be Wernicke's.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, treatment for Wernicke's is thiamine; we gave her that together with the vino.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Delirium points to lithium, I know we didn't find any but--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She had to be smuggling it in to be getting sicker.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Whipple's causes encephalopathic delirium.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Test was negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The test could have been wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ideas are not soda cans, recycling sucks. Give me something new and shiny. Or go retro, take an old idea, shine it up, add a new symptom... encephalopathic delirium. Pellagra.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She drinks. Alcoholics get pellagra. They eat lousy diets so no niacin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He agrees with me, what a shock.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But you're right, lack of niacin starves the brain, neurons shut down, causes seizures, encephalopathic delirium and psychosis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We give Kara niacin, she'll come out of her delirium and she'll be totally sane.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don't think she's ever going to be sane again. Her son just died.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How do you feel?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Err... my err... stomach kinda hurts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I need to ask you some questions, see how you're doing.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tell me your name?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Kara Mason, is my son here?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When were you born?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Please, where is Michael? Is he ok?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do you hear any other voices besides mine?

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: No! Answer me!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You've been suffering from delusions. They were caused by a vitamin deficiency, pellagra. Made you believe things that were not real.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Like the voices. I err... remember doing things to Mikey... were those real?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm afraid so.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: So I...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You tried to suffocate your son.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: But I... you... you stopped me. And err... that... that other doctor, he got Mikey breathing...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your sonâ€™s organs were damaged too severely. He passed away this morning.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Oh nooo! No no no noooo! Noooo! Oh my god, no! Oh my god!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pellagra doesn't cause bloody vomit. She's still sick and getting worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So... what causes pellagra and crimson spew? Dead baby, while sad, not our problem.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I should have given him more polystyrene.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You killed him, if you don't get over it, you're going to kill momma too.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her alcoholism caused the pellagra, maybe it also explains the vomiting. Gastritis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Gastritis meds aren't helping, which may confirm her story she only slipped once.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You remove the drinking from the equation, internal bleeding, hypercalcemia, seizure and pellagra are all back in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase, would you get your head out of the dead baby's butt and focus on the barely alive-- How much polystyrene did you give the kid?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: One gram. His potassium just kept rising.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need your son.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your wife's doctor. Your son may have had the same condition she does.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: My son didn't have a condition, she killed him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I biopsy her intestines, she'll bleed out. He obviously won't.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: You're not using my son's body to help her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok. How about trading him for a beer? Or maybe you're more of a whiskey guy. You didn't have strep or stomach bug the morning you came in, you puked because you were hung over. If she was a recovering drunk and slipping most of the time, you'd be right.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: So I drink. You're acting like this is my fault.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People are going to feel sorry for you; they'll tell you that you can't anticipate the unthinkable well the fact is you can. It's just not all that pleasant.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: Look, you don't know anything about how--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know that people don't get crazy enough to kill someone without first being crazy enough for someone to notice. How many times did you go out for a drink because she was crying? How many times did you stay at work because you couldn't listen to her telling you what a bad mother she is? You were relieved. When she shut down. She just sat staring for hours at a time. She held the pillow over his head; you slept while she went nuts. Not exactly a draw but--

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: What is wrong with you? What kind of a person says those things now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Let me do the test. It'll be one less thing for you to feel crappy about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got a dead baby for you to autopsy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Let Cameron do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Love working NICU? I can get you transferred.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I told you, I just wanted to trust patients.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't give a crap about patients. Your paycheck. You've been double-dipping. Taking your vacation time here while drawing a salary in NICU. Strange - rich boy doing all that for some extra cash.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm not rich.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But your dad was; now he's dead. If you're not rich that means that daddy cut you out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm not rich.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't let it change you. And do the test.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: God of compassion, take Michael into your arms, welcome him into paradise. There will be no sorrow, no weeping and no pain. Peace and joy forevermore. I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It was a date. Cuddy's negative for all cancer markers. It was a date.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Baby's intestines show slight villus atrophy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How would a baby have flattened villi?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He was being treated with polystyrene.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Polystyrene shouldn't--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It didn't. Question is what do they use in the NICU to bind it together?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Wheat gluten.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's great stuff. Unless your body can't tolerate it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The baby didn't have colic he had celiac disease?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just like mom. Celiac can be triggered by all kinds of stress. Bills, childbirth, drunk husband. Every time she had a bowl of pasta or a slice of bread a slosh of soya sauce, her small intestine became more damaged, less able to absorb the vitamins and minerals in her bloodstream. Her body couldn't absorb enough niacin, caused the pellagra. Didn't absorb vitamin K, caused the bleeding. And celiac is why the baby's meds didn't work. His body just couldn't absorb them. Switch mom to IV nutrition, its gluten free, that'll spruce her villi right up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, celiac causes nutritional deprivation. Our patient has excess calcium.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell them what causes excess calcium. With a chaser of bloody vomit.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Celiac patients are susceptible to cancer of the stomach lining. She has MALT lymphoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, she's your patient now. And it wasn't a date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You don't have dwarfism.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have no proof of that. I on the other hand, have this.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You ran a PCR on me without my consent?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, it's good news.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Really? It's just hard to access because of this overwhelming sense of personal violation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Deal with it on your own time. Bad news, oestrogen is too high.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No matter how many people you tell otherwise, I am and always have been a woman. Oestrogen is normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not this much, not for at least for another week. That's when you ovulate.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You monitor my periods? Based on when I get bitchy or...?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Once a month, when you leave the kids cancer ward, your eyes glisten. About three days later, you break your ban on sugar and chow down a bucket of frozen yoghurt in the cafeteria, sprinkles included. Based on the last yoghurt sighting, you've got another week before you ovulate. You're on fertility meds. With red clover as an herbal booster. And the dinner with Wilson was an audition. It's too bad he didn't land the gig. He would have had fun.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was considering a donation, not a party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So... when's our "dinner"?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh he's going to be so disappointed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right. You two are going to have a lot of fun with this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your patient won't let me touch her.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: I killed my son.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is it my turn to say something obvious now? Oh I know, you were insane.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: I did it. I chose to do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, like diabetics choose to not produce insulin. Listen, someone got sick, someone died. Happens every day. The only difference in this case is it wasn't the same someone.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: I could have stopped. I didn't have to listen to those voices.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spoken like a true sane person. This is not your fault. You're healthy now... except for the cancer.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Those voices felt as real to me as Michael's hand. Right here when he nursed. And... the smell of his hair...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You do not deserve to die.

utterance.speaker: Kara
utterance.content: Maybe. I don't want to live.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She said no.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So we get her declared unstable, appoint a medical proxy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She was unstable, now she's sane. She's entitled to refuse treatment.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We have to change her mind, you can't just walk away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine, go on in there and tell her that every day is a blessing! So you killed your baby, shake it off, think positive! At least you're alive. Hmm. Kinda hard to sell when you don't believe it huh? And you never believed it. You just wanted all that crap you went through to mean something, well it didn't mean anything, it never does. Welcome back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why are you doing this to me? I was happy!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You were aspiring to be content.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Don't give me a semantic argument. I was content with the way things were! That's what happiness is!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, if we're all just satisfied with what we have, what a beautiful world it would be. We'd all slowly starve to death in our own filth, but at least we'd be happy. Listen, I need your self-worth to hang on this job. I need you kicking ass here to be all that lets you rise above being miserable, if waking up in the morning is enough, I don't need you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I can live with that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No you can't. Not anymore.

utterance.speaker: Brent
utterance.content: If you got treatment then maybe we could... When you see Mikey... tell him his dad says he's sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Bye.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did you tell Cuddy that we tested her for cancer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It wasn't a date. Turned out she had some skin lesions, guess there was no genetic predisposition.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You tivo The L Word?
